limitations: High heterogeneity of cohort groups due to multiple competitive levels

Inconsistency in injury definitions across studies

https://openalex.org/W4408557862.level_of_analysis: National Basketball Association (NBA), 2009-2024 regular seasons, all 30 franchises
https://openalex.org/W4408557862.main_result: Analytics department headcount has a positive and statistically significant effect on NBA regular season wins, with each additional analyst contributing approximately 1.25 wins when controlling for roster characteristics, injuries, and schedule difficulty.
limitations: Manual data collection of analytics staff headcounts from NBAStuffer introduces potential measurement error and risk of nonrandom error if certain teams conceal staff directories or if NBAStuffer systematically underestimates certain organizations
Additional technical personnel may exist beyond publicly available sources that are unaccounted for in the headcount data
Archives for analytics headcount data were sometimes several months before the regular season, assuming no significant off-season changes

Using headcount as a proxy for analytics investment may not capture all aspects of analytics adoption, and increasing headcount does not necessarily improve productivity; financial R&D expenditure would be a better measure but is not publicly available
Cannot account for day-to-day fluctuations in player fatigue, team morale, or on-court playing conditions which all impact team performance
Assumption of independence (A2) is necessarily violated because winning is a zero-sum outcome, though authors argue the effect is minimal with 30 teams

https://openalex.org/W4408618809.level_of_analysis: British junior elite track and field athletes, London and South-East region
https://openalex.org/W4408618809.main_result: Physical and psychological maltreatment, and neglect are indirectly related to subjective vitality via psychological safety in British junior elite track and field athletes.
limitations: Research limited to track and field athletes only; generalizability across other sports unclear
Potential confounding from athletes changing clubs/coaches due to maltreatment during the 12-month measurement period
Did not measure intention to report maltreatment or confidence in being supported when speaking out
Self-report measures may lead to social desirability bias despite anonymity efforts

https://openalex.org/W4408778760.primary_method: repeated measures one-way ANOVA with post-hoc paired t-tests
all_methods: SPM1D (Statistical Parametric Mapping 1D) continuous parameter analysis
https://openalex.org/W4408778760.level_of_analysis: England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) elite fast bowling group; cricket fast bowling front foot contact phase
https://openalex.org/W4408778760.main_result: Increased lower body and shoulder strength resulted in significantly faster ball release speeds (40.7 to 41.5 ms⁻¹, p<0.001) and reduced vertical ground reaction impulse, with greater bowling shoulder extensor torque during mid-phase contact.
limitations: Limited statistical power due to sample size of 10 bowlers
Planar modelling approach limits investigation of non-planar rotations of torso and pelvis
Optimisation procedure examines single set of activation parameters which may not be robust to perturbations
Did not explore effect of strengthening bowling wrist joint or other physical strength qualities

https://openalex.org/W4408782780.software: RStudio v2023.09.1, Posit Software and R v3.6.1
https://openalex.org/W4408782780.main_result: Propulsive force deterioration rate is significantly associated with deceleration rate, maximum velocity, and finish velocity across all sprint events, with event-specific differences suggesting different pacing strategies.
limitations: Reliance on modelling to estimate propulsive force deterioration rather than direct measurement of ground reaction force
Cannot be entirely certain all performances were maximum effort; cannot establish whether lane allocation or wind speed played a significant role from publicly available data
Limited data on track conditions and their impact on races made it infeasible to account for these effects fully
Reaction times were not accounted for in the study
Validity of model assumes constant deceleration rate

all_methods: Discretization techniques (Equal Width Binning, Equal Frequency Binning, Manual Binning, K-Means Clustering)

https://openalex.org/W4408886394.main_result: Small cricket academies face significant barriers to adopting data analytics due to financial constraints (70%), lack of technical expertise (60% of coaches), and reliance on manual data collection methods (85%), while players (90%) recognize the potential benefits but lack access to affordable tools.

https://openalex.org/W4408926403.temporal_scope: preparation phase for the 2024 indoor season

https://openalex.org/W4408926403.main_result: Maximal sprinting speed and maximal aerobic speed are strong predictors of 400m performance (adjusted R² = 0.90), with speed reserve ratio enabling differentiation between sprint-type and endurance-type athletes.
limitations: MSS assessment during early season (non-peak performance)
Single testing day prohibited all-out 400m time-trial
Competition time used rather than season personal best (75 ± 58 days difference)

https://openalex.org/W4408951051.main_result: Teams with good offensive and defensive efficiency statistics concentrated in top-performing clusters when using PCA-reduced variables and K-means clustering, with error rates ranging from 23.3% to 46.67%.
limitations: Simplification of metrics: The exclusion of key metrics like win percentage during PCA analysis, while necessary for reducing redundancy, may overlook some intuitive aspects of team rankings.
Cluster rigidity: The K-Means clustering method assumes predefined cluster numbers (k), which may not always align perfectly with real-world team dynamics.
Error sensitivity: Results depend on the quality of the dataset and preprocessing steps like normalization, making the method sensitive to data imperfections.

https://openalex.org/W4408967593.main_result: The four factors (shooting, turnovers, rebounding, free throws) significantly predict WNBA team success similar to NBA teams, with shooting (42%) being most important, though proportions differ from the original model.

Loss of granularity when combining seasons

https://openalex.org/W4408994927.main_result: A multi-output deep neural network achieved mean Euclidean distance error of 0.154 m in predicting pitch location, outperforming linear regression by 28% (0.061 m difference) and demonstrating that projectile motion context features improve model performance by 17% (2.8 cm).
limitations: All data from single commercial ball tracking system; unclear generalizability to other systems used across different levels of play
Hyperparameter tuning held number of hidden layers constant at 7 across all models; deeper networks with more hidden layers and neurons per layer may have performed better

limitations: Difficulty in determining exactly which lineups create holes due to how homology algorithm works
Homological results can be difficult to interpret geometrically as different geometric holes can correspond to the same homology group
Challenge in condensing hundreds of individual barcodes for collective analysis

https://openalex.org/W4409118698.main_result: Acute endurance exercise increased circulating markers of gastrointestinal integrity (cfDNA, I-FABP, LBP, D-lactate, LPS), with amplified responses when exercising under moderate heat stress (28-30°C vs 18-21°C).
limitations: Small sample size (11 of 18) due to air-conditioning system limitations

https://openalex.org/W4409135013.primary_method: inverse dynamics analysis with musculoskeletal modeling
https://openalex.org/W4409135013.main_result: Reducing breast motion via sports bra support decreased torso flexion angle (~4°) but increased peak lumbar extension spinal joint moments (~0.15 Nm/kg), suggesting that maximizing bounce reduction in bras may increase spinal loading and potential back pain risk.
limitations: Single subject nature of the model and single trial approach may limit generalizability - 'the actual data presented may vary given the individual single subject nature of the model and single trial approach used'

Threshold of 0.05 Nm/kg was reported for male participants and may not apply equally to females - 'The proposed threshold of 0.05 Nm/kg (Hasegawa et al. 2018) as an indicator of possible changes in back pain must be considered given this was reported for male participants and the lumbar spine'

Breast kinematics measured via markers on bra rather than directly on breast tissue - 'although careful bra fit criteria were followed (J. White and Scurr 2012), it may be possible for relative motion between the breast tissue and bra to occur, altering the magnitude of actual breast motion'

https://openalex.org/W4409768736.main_result: All three biofeedback locations (tibial, sacral, and treadmill) demonstrated similarly effective acute reductions in both peak tibial acceleration (16-17%) and peak sacral acceleration (16-17%), with tibial acceleration reductions maintained after feedback removal.
limitations: Study did not screen for runners with high PTA/PSA or those with sustained injuries, limiting generalizability

Results may be misleading up to 5% of the time due to null hypothesis significance testing

https://openalex.org/W4409919552.main_result: Load–velocity relationship variables (L0, v0, and Aline) demonstrated acceptable reliability (CV ≤5.61% and ICC ≥0.83) for monitoring acute changes in lower-body mechanical capacities, with significant reductions in v0 and Aline following high-repetition VBT protocols (30% velocity loss) but not low-repetition protocols (10% velocity loss), despite high individual variability in responses.

Two-point method may be less precise than multiple-load procedures

https://openalex.org/W7128585847.main_result: Double steal attempts with runners on 1st and 2nd base are associated with significantly increased run value (ATE = 0.15, p < 0.001), with the effect more than doubling in 2023 (ATE = 0.339, p < 0.001), while double steals with runners on 1st and 3rd base show no significant benefit.
limitations: Treatment effect estimates averaged over all out states rather than out-specific estimates
Limited variables available in historical Retrosheet data compared to modern player statistics
Small sample size for 2023 runners on 1st and 3rd base situation (32 attempts) precluding reliable propensity score analysis

https://openalex.org/W7128594415.main_result: 11 of 14 studies (79%) reported associations between higher stress levels, reduced sleep quality or duration, and impaired basketball performance across physical, technical, and recovery-related domains.
limitations: Methodological heterogeneity across included studies in measurement approaches and study design
Small sample sizes across included studies (range 7-28 participants)
Predominantly male participants (13/14 studies) and limited population diversity with most studies from professional/elite/NCAA populations

https://openalex.org/W7128600968.primary_method: chi-square and Fisher's exact tests for prevalence comparisons; t-tests and Mann–Whitney U tests for group differences
https://openalex.org/W7128600968.level_of_analysis: Middle- and long-distance running; Japanese university track and field club and club sports teams; American Division I cross-country and university-affiliated club teams
https://openalex.org/W7128600968.main_result: Japanese female runners had higher prevalence of energy deficiency risk factors (56% vs. 32%), history of stress fractures (50% vs. 17%), and all three Triad components (42% vs. 16%) compared to American runners, despite similar menstrual function and BMI.
limitations: Use of two different DXA scanners (GE Lunar iDXA in USA; Hologic Discovery A in Japan)
Different assay platforms for TT3 and IGF-1 measurements between countries
Self-report nature of food records, menstrual history, and medical history
Lack of pediatric database in American DXA scanner for participants under age 20, requiring cross-calibration and Z-score calculations

https://openalex.org/W7128609913.level_of_analysis: athletics throwing events: shot put, discus throw, javelin throw, hammer throw
https://openalex.org/W7128609913.main_result: Anthropometric characteristics including height, body mass, arm length, shoulder width, and lean body mass are determinant factors for performance in athletics throwing events, with event-specific requirements varying between shot put, discus, hammer, and javelin throw.

https://openalex.org/W7128620811.primary_method: Pearson correlation and ordinary least products regression
all_methods: Bootstrap resampling with bias-corrected and accelerated (BCa)
https://openalex.org/W7128620811.software: IBM SPSS Statistics version 30.0.0.0, MATLAB 2019b, Microsoft Excel
https://openalex.org/W7128620811.temporal_scope: during Japanese Women's National Basketball Team training camp
https://openalex.org/W7128620811.main_result: Sacrum-mounted IMU acceleration demonstrates significant correlation with ground reaction force during 180° change of direction tasks in elite female basketball players, with task-specific relationships: stronger during lateral shuffle than during 180° turns.
limitations: Small homogeneous sample of 14 elite/world-class female basketball players with limited generalizability to male or sub-elite cohorts

IMU secured via specialized sleeve and clip to clothing, making complete elimination of sensor displacement challenging and potentially explaining lower intrasession reliability in peak horizontal acceleration during right-foot 180° turn

Force-plate and IMU time series aligned post hoc without hardware synchronization, restricting analysis to peak metrics and precluding robust comparisons of impulse, contact-time, and force-time derived measures

https://openalex.org/W7128630577.primary_method: Mann-Whitney U tests and independent t-tests
https://openalex.org/W7128630577.level_of_analysis: NCAA regulation 3-point distance (6.75 m), NCAA regulation basket height (305 cm)
https://openalex.org/W7128630577.main_result: Proficient 3-point shooters demonstrated significantly greater hip, knee, and ankle flexion during the preparatory phase, resulting in a lower center of mass and higher hip angular velocities, but no significant differences in kinematic variables at ball release compared to non-proficient shooters.
limitations: sample was homogeneous, consisting exclusively of male basketball players, and did not include athletes competing across different levels of play
sample size was relatively small, which may limit the generalizability of the findings
playing positional differences were not considered and variations in anthropometrics across positions could influence shooting mechanics
experimental design did not account for the presence of a defender, which has been shown to alter shooting execution

https://openalex.org/W7128635573.level_of_analysis: athletics throwing events (shot put, discus throw, javelin throw, hammer throw)
https://openalex.org/W7128635573.main_result: Anthropometric characteristics such as height, body mass, arm length, and shoulder width are fundamental determinants of performance in athletics throwing events, with event-specific profiles being necessary for optimal performance.

https://openalex.org/W7128711079.level_of_analysis: Al-Qasim Green University, College of Physical Education and Sports Sciences, Iraq - 100-meter sprint athletics
https://openalex.org/W7128711079.main_result: Emotional stability contributes 46.2% and psychological security contributes 38.4% to 100-meter sprint performance among first-year students, with statistically significant negative correlations (r=-0.68 and r=-0.62 respectively) indicating that higher psychological stability is associated with faster sprint times.
limitations: Sample limited to first-year students only
No mention of controlling for confounding variables such as training history or physical fitness level
Cross-sectional design limits causal inference
